articles.headline: Can Trump Casinos Keep Up With the Neighbors?
articles.snippet: Saddled with a huge debt, the three Atlantic City casinos need to reinvent themselves for a new Atlantic City.
articles.abstract: Saddled with a huge debt, the three Atlantic City casinos need to reinvent themselves for a new Atlantic City.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTIC CITY — Two of the three casinos here that bear his name rank dead last in terms of gambling revenues among the 11 casinos in town. And in an industry that sometimes seems like a legal means of printing money, his casino holding company lost $19 million last year — in no small part because it is freighted with a staggering $1.4 billion in debt.

articles.headline: Imus Struggling to Retain Sway as a Franchise
articles.snippet: Whether Don Imus can use a meeting with the Rutgers women’s basketball team to save his career is unclear.
articles.abstract: Whether Don Imus can use a meeting with the Rutgers women’s basketball team to save his career is unclear.
articles.lead_paragraph: That Don Imus can be abrasive and offensive is undeniable, but he is also one of the most successful and influential pitchmen in the history of radio, if not broadcasting.

articles.headline: A Word of Advice During a Housing Slump: Rent
articles.snippet: For years, homeownership made more sense than renting. But now it is clear that people who chose renting over buying in the last two years made the right move.
articles.abstract: For years, homeownership made more sense than renting. But now it is clear that people who chose renting over buying in the last two years made the right move.
articles.lead_paragraph: A promotional spot for the National Association of Realtors came on the radio the other day. The spot, introduced as something called “Newsmakers,” was supposed to sound like a news report, with the association’s president offering real estate advice.

articles.headline: China Conveys ‘Regret’ Over Trade Complaints
articles.snippet: The American decision to complain to the World Trade Organization will “seriously undermine” relations on trade, the Chinese government said.
articles.abstract: The American decision to complain to the World Trade Organization will “seriously undermine” relations on trade, the Chinese government said.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, Wednesday, April 11 — The Chinese government expressed “deep regret and strong dissatisfaction” on Tuesday with the Bush administration’s decision to file two complaints against China with the World Trade Organization.

articles.headline: Some in G.O.P. Express Worry Over ’08 Hopes
articles.snippet: Party leaders are concerned about dissatisfaction with the president and political fallout from the war in Iraq.
articles.abstract: Party leaders are concerned about dissatisfaction with the president and political fallout from the war in Iraq.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 10 — Republican leaders across the country say they are growing increasingly anxious about their party’s chances of holding the White House, citing public dissatisfaction with President Bush, the political fallout from the war in Iraq and the problems their leading presidential candidates are having generating enthusiasm among conservative voters.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and John M. Broder

articles.headline: Purveyor to the Queen Faces Test From Wal-Mart
articles.snippet: The Loblaw Companies, Canada’s largest grocery chain and once one of North America’s most innovative retailers, is struggling with inventory problems and its first annual loss in 19 years.
articles.abstract: The Loblaw Companies, Canada’s largest grocery chain and once one of North America’s most innovative retailers, is struggling with inventory problems and its first annual loss in 19 years.
articles.lead_paragraph: OTTAWA, April 9 — When Queen Elizabeth needs groceries, her staff usually sends out to Fortnum & Mason. Household goods at Buckingham Palace often come from the Selfridges department store. And the tea poured at royal tea parties is likely to have been blended by R. Twining & Company.

articles.headline: Take-Two’s Mr. Fix-It Inherits a Handful
articles.snippet: Strauss Zelnick has taken on risky corporate restructurings before, but he says none have been as complex as at Take-Two Interactive Software, where he was named chairman two weeks ago.
articles.abstract: Strauss Zelnick has taken on risky corporate restructurings before, but he says none have been as complex as at Take-Two Interactive Software, where he was named chairman two weeks ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: The closest Strauss Zelnick usually gets to playing video games is watching over the shoulders of his two young sons. Mr. Zelnick concedes that his gaming skills are better suited for Pong and Pac-Man than Grand Theft Auto, the smash hit from the company that he is now in charge of turning around.

articles.headline: A Mosque Raid Sets Off Sunnis in Iraq’s Capital
articles.snippet: The daylong battle in the neighborhood of Fadhil appeared to be the fiercest since the start of the new security plan.
articles.abstract: The daylong battle in the neighborhood of Fadhil appeared to be the fiercest since the start of the new security plan.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, April 10 — Sunni militants and residents of the Baghdad neighborhood of Fadhil fought a fierce daylong battle with the Iraqi Army and American soldiers on Tuesday in what appeared to be the most sustained confrontation since the start of the security plan to calm violence in the capital.

articles.headline: Sea’s Rise in India Buries Islands and a Way of Life
articles.snippet: Thirty-one square miles of river delta islands near the Bay of Bengal have vanished in the last 30 years.
articles.abstract: Thirty-one square miles of river delta islands near the Bay of Bengal have vanished in the last 30 years.
articles.lead_paragraph: GHORAMARA ISLAND, India — Shyamal Mandal lives at the edge of ruin.
